segments.text: Is Admiral Redfield still alive?
Yes.
Is he somewhere around this area?
Yes, he is.
Lives right up here.
Wonderful person.
I want to go see him.
Okay.
All right.
You're at Pearl Harbor, then?
At Pearl Harbor.
This is at Pearl Harbor in the spring of 1944.
Having been sent there as a representative of the Bureau of Ships to offer my services to Commander Submarine's Pacific Fleet in
largely in connection with the bath demographic, but in any way one can be useful.
This entailed one or two trips, side trips, to Midway to catch submarines there.
There was a large number of submarines at Pearl.
What I tried to do was to see as many people as I could to distribute
Really, it was an educational trip, both for them and for us.
And I tried to report pretty regularly back to both the Woods Hole and to Revell in Washington to let them know what we might be able to do better.
Admiral Lockwood was sub-pac.
His assistant operations officer

was then Commander Grenfell, who was the most senior oceanographer, who was the most senior submarine man I had had any long acquaintance with because he had been involved in the Bureau of Ships in Washington.
I would like to relate one discussion I had with Admiral Grenfell when I arrived out there.
And incidentally, I had great respect for Grenfell then and have continued to
over the many years that I have known him as being a man who works very hard for his boys, the submarine people.

Well, when I got out there, I looked up Grenfell and said, Commander, I'd like very much to have you listen to what I have to say because I don't know very much about submarines, and I know that I know a great deal more about than any of my bosses did in Washington or

at Woods Hole, and when I give them a line of patter in the Atlantic, that's one thing, but when you talk to them at Pearl or Midway when they're about to start out on a patrol, one feels a little bit more serious.
Well, Grenfell listened for a little while, and then
He said, Alan, I wouldn't really worry very much.
He said, first, I think most of what you have to say makes pretty good sense.
And for the rest of it, I think oceanography, the rest of it, I think submarine people are smart enough not to pay any attention to it.
Well, many times since, when I have been giving a talk or something like that, and my nerve has kind of wavered, I remember what Grenfell have said.
said, and felt, you're talking to adults.
You tell them what you think they ought to know, and let them make up their own mind.
Well, this general sense prevailed in Pearl Harbor.
We took many manuals with us, and we had a magnificent opportunity to teach.
And this was real teaching.

One of the things we quickly found out was you go through the ship, inspect their apparatus, and see if it was working, and if not, do whatever was necessary to get the people on the beach to fix anything that you couldn't.
Then you go to the junior officer and find out what reports he had, a piece of paper he had to do with the bath thermograph.
And you might find that he had not all very little, or you might find that he had a lot of junk that was obsolete, and you could help him throw it away.
One of the most important things you could do was to get stuff off the ship.
Then, if somebody was going out on patrol, you seldom knew exactly what they were doing, because...
People like technicians were not cleared for such information unless what they were working on affected the expedition very much.
But you quickly found out that after the captain knew where he was sent,
Then you sit down with he and his sonar officer and by this time you knew the month that was involved.
You knew the general area either from what he sort of blocked it out or which particular areas that he was paying the most attention to.
Then you could take a red grease pencil, and you could start circling the few paragraphs in a thick document that might really affect him.
You could circle, indicate the graphs.
You were doing him the most favor if you tore all the other pages out of the book and threw them away, and then wrote about a one-page addendum that would be most pertinent
for him and what he sometimes felt was his particular way that he liked to make an attack or some such thing as this.
Brevity, brevity, brevity, and fundamentalism, because these were smart people.
And if you could give them the principle of what you were after, they were apt to, about a half of them or a third of them would do very well.
As I've said earlier, these were the people that at later dates and later jobs, they were some of the best friends that oceanography and science ever had.
Over the years, they frequently had much higher standards for oceanography than the oceanographers themselves.
And many times when we used their submarines, whether they were
operational officers on the staffs who were there running the submarines themselves.
They went beyond the call of duty to see that things got done.
Well, we come to the end of the war.
And here, of course, it was the end of the war in the Pacific that counted, because in the submarine navy, it was almost entirely the Pacific.
This was a period, of course, in which
We visited quite a few of the laboratories.
The Navy laboratories, oceanographic laboratories were involved in a good deal of touring around amongst each other's laboratories, helping each other out.
The cooperation was wonderful.
Let me short one thing here.
You have three papers that really come out of this submarine work in 1946, don't you?
Yes.
Okay.
Well...
The one on underwater photography comes out in 1946.
Yes.
And then two that come out on the submarines.
I think this was from data you collected here at Woodrow?
Most of the work that was...
Most of the submarine work that was done never really came out as a report except it came out most in the summary...
In the technical reports, in the bound technical reports that the NDRC published at the end of the war, these have been declassified.
There aren't very many of them around.
We took the general trend that, in my own case, it seemed like it was a better thing not to publish too much of that stuff.
Because when you make friends with a few hundred people in the silent service, you develop a tendency to respect their general thoughts and way of operation.
The sound channel work and some of the acoustics work that was done
done by Ewing and Warzel, of which I was in on much in the beginning, but only the periphery at the end.
These were things which really the Navy wasn't particularly interested in at the end of the war, because they felt it was not important to anti-submarine warfare work and so forth.
So that was published rather quickly.
At the end of the war, Project Crossroads
the concept of testing of these new nuclear devices came along.
Revell was a great ringleader in that in Washington.
And for the Bikini tests in the summer of 46, Project Crossroads, quite a large number of oceanographers got out there.
In fact, at one time, there were about 40 people from Woods Hole
Many of these were hired for the job on radiological safety work.

But my involvement was largely through Revell, but it was with a wave measurement group in which we were trying to see how high the waves would be that were caused by the atomic blast, both the air blast and the underwater blast.
From Woods Hole, an engineer, Otis Hunt, who worked with me on instruments, went.
Sever Harlow, who was a mechanic over at the Marine Biological Laboratory and quit to go out with us.
He also was a very junior sailor mechanic at the time the NC boats flew across the Atlantic.
So
He was interested in this sort of thing.
And John Parkinson, who was sort of a junior Harvard classmate of Columbus's and had been a DE skipper during the war, and he felt it would be very interesting to see this bomb and its effects.
We were attached to the submarine tender Fulton
out in Pearl and to go out to Bikini.

They worked very hard getting ready with our equipment, which our primary equipment consisted of about a dozen instruments which we called turtles that were steel cases with recording clocks and pressure gauges that would basically try and measure the height of the wave that passed over them.
The
important part of these instruments, where they were completely self-contained.
There was no electronics associated with them.
And we felt that they might not give the best data in the world, but they would give data.
And knowing that so many things could go wrong, we felt that was important.
On the Fulton, they had a variety of people from other laboratories.
I was particularly interested to get to know better people like John Isaacs from Scripps and then at the University of California and Scripps, who were measured in the wave measurement group.
This whole thing has slowed up a little bit because just after we sailed from California, we received word that the tests were going to be postponed for about a month.
Rather than turning around and going back with all the confusion, I decided to stay out in Pearl for that time, as most of the others.
This gave us a chance to give some proper testing to our apparatus, which had received only a disgraceful small amount of testing before we left Woods Hole.
And it also gave me a chance to...
go to the submarine base and see what the chances were of continuing some of the tests on particularly the submerged performance characteristics of submarines.
We had done a bit of this during the war, which came about because really of the density layers.
We would tell submarines
that a dense layer would amount to a ton, and some of them would laugh and say, but we have other problems with our boats, which are much more important than that.
And it was very clear that they had no document that told them how their submarine operated underwater.
They had no sets of curves or vertical motions.
vertical turning circles, things like this.
And much of their folklore was very good.
Much of their folklore was very bad.
And it was extremely difficult for junior officers to learn to dive their boat quickly because they had no sound, reasonably sound, even thumb rules to go by.
This was a little flabbergasting.
to us.
We'd run into it early and did some things about it.

In fact, we helped the Ascania Regulator Company make modifications to the submarine diving trainer so they could put temperature gradients into the fictitious ocean which these submarine trainers dove into.
Of the kinds of things we were interested in here was, could a submarine sit on a density layer?
For example, if they lost all power in the war zone, would they have to surface and surrender or shoot it out when they were outgunned a hundredfold or surrender, or would they
Let her sink to the bottom, or might they be able to set out on a density layer?
And we had experiments.
One of the first ones was on the darter, in which we got the submarine skipper to get a stop trim at periscope depth, flood in about a ton of water when he was dead in the water, and let it sink.
At that time, we had a density.
fairly good thermal layer at about 180 feet.
All the time we were sinking, the way the crew was trying to lay bets with you is how high would you bet that the submarine would stop when it hit the density layer or keep on sinking.
And we had a good density layer.
It was just like falling into a feather bed.
But the nice thing that it showed was that we only
exceeded the neutral depth by about 10 or 12 feet.
And this was one of the early tests that showed us that the submarines could rely on this density layer.
We did other tests like this, one on the batfish, in which we flooded in water at about, flooded in
about 5,000 pounds at periscope depth when we were stopped to see how rapidly we would fall.
And a submarine has a lot of resistance when you try and push it sideways.
So you really have a couple of minutes, even though you're perhaps 10,000 pounds heavy, a submarine without any propulsion at all, if it is dead in the water,
has one and a half or two minutes before it gets to collapse depth.

So if a skipper can take advantage of this extra time and find out what is wrong with a submarine, then he may be able to fix something or have a bright idea before he gets into real extremis and before he surfaces, which is one of the most dangerous things they can do.
Well, this particular time on the Batfish was very interesting because it tells something about the submarine operator's character.
The captain turned the dive over to me, and we fell gracefully and smoothly, taking the date as we went, down to about 200 feet.
And then we went down to about 300 feet.
The data was coming along very well, and I had about all I wanted.
I sort of indicated to the captain that he could take over, and he indicated, no, keep going.
So we got down to test depth, and then we went a little bit deeper, and I figured there's no point in playing chicken with that particular commanding officer.
So in a loud, clear voice, I said, Captain, the test is satisfactorily completed.
I turn the boat back over to you.
And the captain, quick as a wink, picked up the general communication system in the submarine.
And as part of his education program, he said, attention all hands.
Our visiting scientist oceanographer friend, he said, now that we are past test depth, 8,000 pounds heavy, dead in the water,

falling past test depth our oceanographer scientist friend has turned the submarine back to the captain I thank him blow safety well this was a magnificent opportunity the captain wanted everybody on the ship to know the status he had been advising them so that when he blew safety and we started going back up again they could say hey
Everybody on the ship would know that this was something which was foreseen, predictable, and when it happened, it was something they could count on in the future.
We're back out at Operations Crossroads at Pearl Harbor while we were waiting for Operations Crossroads.
Captain Grenfell had by this time become a captain of squadron commander, and he turned the boat over to us for about a week to go out and do testing of what we would do each morning.
We would...

We would do testing of free falls, such things, and such things as telling how much the boat would tilt as people moved back and forth in it, and trying to quantify the motions of the boat underwater.
And then in the afternoon, we would plan everything so the battery would be run pretty well dead by late afternoon.
And we would try and see what combinations of bow and stern planes would give what diving characteristics, how quickly one could pull out of deep dives, high angles, and so forth.
Perhaps the most important part about this was not that the tests themselves, because they were fairly simple and fundamental, but the report was written up
In one week, the report was written up, duplicated, and sent out to every submarine in the Pacific Fleet.
So this was an indication of the fact that communication was working.
In this discussion of submarine performance, I don't want to leave the impression that some of us at Woods Hole knew more about submarines than the operators.
This was not the case at all.
What it amounted to...
was that we would sometimes talk some of their bosses into getting some time so the submarine people could do some tests, which many of them would like to have done anyhow.
What we tended to do was to systemize the approach so that the things that were done could come out with a little bit simpler thumb rolls so the junior people could learn a little faster.

And what we felt was equally important, that the senior people might be able to take these same ground rules and, in cases of extremis, could estimate a little further how far the design of their boat and the constitution of the ocean would permit them to go.
Getting back to Crossroads.
It was, in my way of thinking, a really wonderful set of tests.

And the fact that the vast majority of the work was unclassified, that they had foreign observers, and the fact that this information of this new device got out into the world at large in a quantitative fashion.
I think the job of the Defense Department and the
Atomic Energy Commission and so forth did in writing this information up was really a great service to mankind.
I'm not approving of the fact that it would be just as nice if we didn't have the bomb, but that is a matter of reality.
It is very important that people know what they have.
Military people and civilians all over the world realize they have a different kind of beast than they had before.
In general, the tests out there were fairly successful, the tests we were involved with.
But it was an opportunity to work with a good many people.
Some very simple instrumentation.
We had our one set of instrumentation at the bottom.

Some of you may notice, if you see the most common picture of the underwater blast, showing this great mushroom going up in the water, going up the column of water, going up in the air, that in some of these pictures, there's a pine, there's a palm tree in the foreground.
And on the palm tree, next to the palm tree, there's a stepladder.
And on the palm tree, there are some tin cans nailed.
These are wave gauges in case the water got so high that it went up over the land and tried to cover up the palm tree.
Only reason I mention that is because we tried there, as most of the field workers I have acquainted with, whom I have great respect for,
know perfectly well that in the field almost anything can happen.
And one should aim an experiment so that you get some kind of data almost no matter how the experiment goes or what particularly casually fate plays on you at the moment.
Coming back to Woods Hole in the fall of 46, summer of 46 after Crossroads, there were several changes.
One, Ewing had gone to Columbia University with Warzel.
A good many of the wartime people were pulling out to bracket Hersey, Columbus University,
Columbus Island got Brackett Hersey to come in and head up an acoustics group, head up the acoustics group.
At that time, I believe I was listed as, started off as a physicist.
I think along about that time, Columbus classified me as a physical oceanographer.
I suppose largely because I'd been spending a lot of my time on physical oceanography, but principally because he was into the kind of work we were doing.
He was a physical oceanographer, and he probably thought that the best work was done by physical oceanographers.
So he'd just put his little clan and call them physical oceanographers.
Fritz Fuglester was far more of a physical oceanographer and had been.
spending nearly all of his time on that kind of thing, where I'd only been spending a peripheral length of time.
But on the other hand, as I indicated earlier, one of the relationships that we had in jobs ahead was, how do you talk to submarine people?
How do you think about oceanography and underwater sound on a global basis, at least a Western Pacific basis?
About this time after Crossroads, Roger Revelle left the Bureau of Ships and moved over to the newly formed Office of Naval Research.
It asked me if I would take over his job in the Bureau of Ships.
This I did not want to do, but I said I would do it half time.
My personal position was that I had just bought a house only about 200 yards from the Oceanographic Institution.
I had the feeling that, well, I really should solve the commuting problem.
Then I signed on for three years, spending every other week in Washington, which shows you win some, you lose some.

Working in Washington was extremely interesting, and I was very glad that I did it, and I heartily recommend that many more people get a job in Washington, also particularly in the formative period of their lives.
Roger was administering the bulk of oceanography at that time in the country,
And for a while there, well, he was administering the bulk of oceanography in the country.

So for a while, I was in this desk, was probably administering, in fact, I think probably a higher percentage of the funding of civilian oceanography than anybody has since, because there wasn't much other.
That was that simple.
Roger left.
a great deal of unfinished business about a whole file cabinet full of unanswered correspondence.

And the only stipulation I made with Roger when I took the job was that it would not be necessary for him to pass on anything, that I would not have to wait for him to do anything because he tended to be slow and meticulous.
I knew I'd never get through that cabinet.
This was no problem.
Roger was a wonderful person to deal with, and I spent a great deal of time with him while he was in ONR.
The several things that I got out of that job was, first, one thing.
